Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2009 10:03AM Lindissima wrote: Athena, Kira, Virginia, and all, Thanks for the great links!  I've got my work cut out for me. This has been  quite a wake up call for me regarding Susan Love.  When I was initially dx'ed,  there was another very MAJOR trauma going on in my life, which  severely limited my ability to do lots of research for the first month before treatment.  I spoke with several women who had been treated for BC about 15 years ago, all of whom enthusiastically recommended her book to me.  Several women, including medical professionals, warned me to 'stay away from those internet boards.' Consequently, I based a lot of my  initial decisions on her book.(though I did consult medical sites like NCI, medical journals  and something in UK) I only ventured onto this board in June, and have found it to be an incredibly rich resource, not only for information, but for support and validation of my experience during this journey.  Treasure trove is a very apt description, thank you Athena for putting it so eloquently. That's not to say we should believe everything posted here without question or a healthy dose of skepticism. We have to verify and reverify every bit of information  we  use to guide us in our decision making, whether it comes from Susan Love, our own doctors  or a website.  I also appreciate the women who jump in to point out errors when someone has posted some misinformation. I believe for the most part this is not done maliciously. I  feel the more I read here, the more my eyes are opened.  Thanks to all who contribute.
Posts.Title: Susan Love proclaims no need for lymphedema risk reductions kira TammyLou

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2011 08:44PM Lindissima wrote: Indiana, I am so sorry you have to go through this stressful time.   All I can advise you  is what helped me: take it one step at a time.  You are going to the US tomorrow and that will give you one bit more of information. Chances are good you will be in the clear.  Yo are doing the right thing by having supportive people come with you. I had 3 US around the time of my diagnosis  and I remember them as being fairly brief. I really don't remember much about the experience, I just went 'someplace else' in my head. As suggested above, I think you should talk to the technician about your discomfort with the situation.  I'm sure she will do everything she can to put you at ease. The tech will be focused on what she sees on the screen. I will be saying a prayer for you tonight.  Take good care of yorself.  We are here if you need us.
Posts.Title: US tomarrow morning - scared IndianaMomOf3 adgra

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 10:52AM Lindissima wrote: Sparrow, I found holding one position for a long time during the planning phase to be uncomfortable, but very tolerable. If you still have residual pain from surgery, the tylenol previously suggested is a good idea. The tatoos were quick and  not painful at all.  (and only one of mine is even visible)  The CT, my first, wasn't bad either.  Donut hole, so I didn't feel claustrophobic.  My center has a lovely illuminated map of the night sky overhead  to look at while one gets treatment.  They also played relaxing music. I agree with Bren, get a peek at the room and ask if they play music.  Some places even let you bring in your own CD's. The tech's were super friendly and suportive too.  All in all, for me, the easiest part of the whole thing. You will be fine.  Take care and  let us know how it went.

So I had a good time going out to lunch with friends on doctor's orders.  Now I am back on a diet trying to lose weight  again and the scale won't budge.  ( thanks to Arimidex)  Oh well... Bon apetit!

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2010 05:29PM Lindissima wrote: Here is a link to the  recent results of the ZO-Fast study on use of Zometa.  Efficacy of Zoledronic Acid in Postmenopausal Women With Early Breast Cancer Receiving Adjuvant Letrozole: 36-Month Results of the ZO-FAST Study - OncologySTAT TAKE-HOME MESSAGE After a 36-month follow-up period, early initiation of ZOL (Zometa) provided significant benefits in bone health and improved DFS in postmenopausal women receiving adjuvant AI therapy for early hormone–receptor positive breast cancer. 3.2% absolute and 41% relative difference between the two groups in terms of recurrance of cancer.  There are other studies on pre-menopausal women as well with similar good results.

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2010 05:57AM Lindissima wrote: Texasdonna, You are doing the right thing by seeing your oncologist immediately and insisting on having the nodule checked out. .As for your grade, that would be on your final pathology report.  I agree that you should call the hospital to get copies of all your reports.  I routinely ask for a  copy of every test and  notes of dr's visits for my records. Oncotype dx testing is not given to everyone. Three years ago it was not as commonly prescribed as it is today; A lot of insurance did not cover it then. I'm sure there are women who can give you more info.  Please let us know how you are anf d how your visit with your onco went.  There are many false positives on MRI's, and I hope yours is too!

I must say I am a bit shy about forcing the issue with my MO as I don't want to alienate him.  If these responses are any indication, I am sure other women are bristling at this too.  Lorithelion and Natsfan, I admire your ability to stand up for yourself. Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2010 01:47AM - edited Jan 24, 2010 04:23AM by Lindissima Dear Lotstolivefor, Sorry to hear you are having a hard time.  Fear is a natural reaction, but getting good information both here and frim your doctors can ease your mind. I noticed that your diagnosis stated Stage one, but your tumor size is over 2 cm.  That would be stage 2.  In that case, radiation is certainly warranted.  There are web sites posted earlier that deal with recurrence rates based on size of margins. You need to discuss your concerns with your rad onc and medical oncologist for the best explanation of risks and benefits. I had 25 rounds of radiation on the right side, and had no significant problems with it, other than a bit of skin burning and tiredness around the three week point.  Many women sail through rads.  Are you in a support group?  There you would meet other women going through rads who could give you some idea what to expect, though everyone is different in how they react. I found rads comforting in that they reduced my risk or recurrence by 50% and gave me more piece of mind.  Good luck !

Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2012 03:41PM Lindissima wrote: Thanks to  you all for your excellent replies.  I have decided to see the NP for one visit, then request my next visit  be with  my oncologist. (I go every 6 months).  I have been told contradictory things about whether or not I may continue to see just the onco. My friend, who is Stage IV is very happy with the NP, so I thought I would give her a chance. At my  National Comprehensive Care teaching hospital, I am not allowed to change oncos.  I would have to leave the system and that would not be a good option.  I really liked my oncologist  and the general level of care at my hospital prior to this  and do feel this was not my onco's  decision, but made by 'higher ups.'.  It is part of the whole movement towards 'cost control' by cutting back access to MD's and moving  from face to face interaction  to 'online surveys'. Accorditng to the  'Survivorship' web page , I was supposed to  have gone to a workshop to prepare me for what this transition would mean, but I was never told about it.  I plan to call the coordinator of the Survivorship Program and voice my concerns.
Posts.Title: "Dumped" by my oncologist after 3 years Lindissima LRM216

Posts.Content: Lindissima wrote: Well 'dumped' may be  too  strong  a word, but that is how I felt.  As my oncologist was leaving  the room after my last appointment, he casually mentioned that I would be seeing the Nurse Practioner instead of him from now on, though I would still be under his care if I needed further treatment. Then he just walked out the door! I was too stunned to protest and felt blindsided.  After asking a few questions of the receptionist, I learned there is a new 'Survivorship Program' women are being transitioned into who are no longer in active treatment at the teaching hospital where I receive treatment. I also learned a friend of mine, who is  2 years into being Stage 4 is also seeing the nurse practioner instead of her onco at the same place. From my reading of these boards, it seems most women here see their onco's for a full five years after diagnosis.I was initially told that is what I would be doing too. I was always careful to have my questions ready and organized so our visits could be efficient. My oncologist was terrific with me during treatment and really went to bat for me, getting me Zometa when it wasn't as commonly used as it is today anong other things.  I really hesitate to leave  his care or the teaching hospital, since they are very well-respected, but I also feel cancer is a very serious disease that needs a real MD monitoring it. I am fine with an NP for many things, but this just makes me uneasy.  I think this is a general policy decision at this hospital, to free the onco's for women in active treatment, also a cost cutting measure. Anyone else happy seeing just an NP? Am I overreacting? Any thoughts?  Dx 1/5/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage IB, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: "Dumped" by my oncologist after 3 years Lindissima LRM216

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2012 04:27PM Lindissima wrote: Thanks again to everyone for your thoughtful replies. I am getting more comfortable with the idea of seeing the NP who my friend sees and really likes.  I will voice my concerns to her, as NP's (and often women in general) are more approachable than doctors. I am stil getting Zometa every 6 months, as per the Austrian protocol, so there are still decisions to be made. SD starfish you are absolutely right...my onc didn't handle this well.  I think he felt uncomfortable doing it as he told me as he rushed out the door--as an after thought.  But thanks again everyone!

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2016 11:53PM Lindissima wrote: Faye33, I haven't been on this site for a while so I apologize for the delaying responding. I am sorry to hear about your recurrence and experience with your MO who really dropped the ball. I am still seeing my NP but she is very young and not very interested in answering questions I may have about studies I have read or research I have done. She also switched me from a diagnostic to a screening mammogram for my last exam. That would mean I would be tested at a different facility with different machines and technicians. The techs I had been seeing for over 5 years knew me well and understood that my cancer was in a place difficult to image. Fortunately my Primary caught it and switched my appointment back to diagnostic. I wish you the best of luck and let us know how your new MO works out.

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 11:05PM - edited Nov 24, 2009 11:14PM by Lindissima Nicole, I'll take a stab at your question.  You said: "My onc says statistically speaking I am 94% unlikely to have a recurrence. This research (on BC.org) says there is a 20ish% chance of recurrence for highly dense breasts." Did your oncologist base your recurrence risk on your Oncotype score? If so, I  the oncotype recurrence rate refers to your risk of distant metastisis (outside the breast, to other organs). The research in the article is talking ablout local recurrence. (in the breast) The article states, "Mammographic density did not appear correlated with metastasis to distant sites." So you may have a higher risk of local recurrence, but the 94% risk of distant recurrence would be the same.  Best to confirm with your oncologist. Good luck!
Posts.Title: CALLING ALL STAGE I SISTERS sheila888 MCBaker

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2011 02:10PM Lindissima wrote: HSMOM, Im sorry about yopur diagnosis.  Mine was over 2 years ago and it did get better once I had my treatment plan in place. I found that having someone take copious notes really helped.  I wrote out all my questions beforehand and gave them to the doctor before the meeting so they could be looked over.  I even had someone record the sessions and I found it very helpful to listen to them again at home.  You don't always 'hear' everything when you are under stress. A second opinion to confirm diagnosis and treatment plan  is always a good idea. I am wishing you all the best.

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2009 11:56AM - edited Oct 11, 2009 10:24PM by Lindissima RE:  Oncotype Dx I am postmenopausal and  used the Oncotype test. I was informed by three oncologists, my surgeon and research I have done that the Oncotype test is very useful for postmenopausal women making a decision on chemotherapy. In  younger women who are premenopausal, some oncologists may disregard a low oncotype score because the feeling is the woman has more time to develop a recurrence.  None of this is written in stone, however, because grade and type of cancer, as well as  patient preference is often taken into account. There are several threads on BCO  on this topic. You can also google Oncotype Dx and either read their site or call the company directly. *New* ~OncoDX~ Roll Call~*New* NEW Oncotype Dx Roll Call Thread London-Virginia:  Have  any studies come out in the UK refuting the validity of the Oncotype test for postmenopausal women?  If so, I'd be interested in reading them.  Thanks.  Wezee:  You are a wonderful sister!  After your sister's final  pathology report comes in, they will know for sure whether her nodes were involved or not.  If your sister is borderline for chemo, they will probably order the ONCOTYPE test to help determine whether she will have chemo or not.

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2010 04:50AM Lindissima wrote: weety, I had the same question.  From the summary extract:  "In the delayed ZOL group, ZOL was provided if the patient’s T-score became < –2.0 after a nontraumatic bone fracture or if an asymptomatic fracture was detected by spinal x-ray." I think the delayed group means they waited until the women had a fracture before prescribing the Zometa. It doesn't really indicate how long a period that was since it probably varied. The other group got the Zometa immediately.  When I started Zometa, I was told to start at the same time I began the arometese inhibitor.  Ask your oncologist.  I don't think one year out is too late.
Posts.Title: Early stage BC and Zometa kathylev weety

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2010 02:48PM - edited Apr 11, 2010 12:56PM by Lindissima Hi Yunlee, 1.  Ask your surgeon to recommend another oncologist for a second opinion.  2.  If possible, take the train to NYC to see someone at Sloan Kettering.  You can do the treatment closer to home later, where it's more convenient. 3.  Take a friend or family member with you to your appointment to listen, take notes and give you support.  I saw 3 oncologists, all said "No chemo" based on my score  of 13. However, I agonized over my decision and my onc said he would give me chemo if I  really wanted it. I finally chose no chemo, but I am stage 1 and over 60 years old.  I am sorry you are going through this.  Please let us know what the second opinion was.
